commit_message:
Add minimum features in HDS driver (for Havana & Icehouse)

* Add create_cloned_volume() api.
* Add extend_volume() api.
* Reorganized some connection state keeping into _loc_info() function.
  Earlier this logic was spread out in various calls.
* New self tests for #1 and #2 above.

Change-Id: I6a88164ee0a427519c7fab6f6a852d46ec46176c
Fixes: bug #1207560

commit_message:
Fix instance_usage_audit_log v3 follow REST principles

Use query parameter 'before' instead of show.
BTW, add expected_errors decorator.

Partially implements bp v3-api-extension-versioning

DocImpact

Change-Id: If1168c01e6342675370acdf278e1c0317aff93d8

'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The repo will certainly be renamed as well. See this commit (in openstack-infra/config) which will do the rename:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/37715/

Initially my plan was to do the rename and then follow it up with this change. See the initial thread here: 

https://groups.google.com/a/puppetlabs.com/forum/#!topic/puppet-openstack/MgIM59GnhAE

At this point it has already been like 3 weeks and I'd rather not have to wait all week to be able to use this. In short I no longer care in which order these branches land.

Quantum is dead... long live neutron."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Chris:

Head is (or should be) targeting Havana. This should land ASAP as it has already been 2-3 weeks since the quantum -> neutron rename.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/52/40252/2/check/gate-puppet-quantum-puppet-lint/81385db : SUCCESS in 6s (non-voting)

http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

patchset 2 is just a rebase. No other changes.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

It looks like a rename will ensure that resources can still be accessed at the old name: 

https://help.github.com/articles/renaming-a-repository

I think for gerrit, maintaining the old name is not necessary.  Given that the core quantum repos were successfully maintained, I think all we have to do is ask that it happen.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

this commit changes the name of classes and defines, which seems to be invalid b/c the name of the actual module is still quantum. Are we eventually going to move the repo as well?'}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Approved

'}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

if everyone is happy with this. I say, let the patches fly!'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I've tested both puppet-quantum & puppet-neutron with rename patches.

I've used Debian packages that we build.

Everything is working.

I think we could merge this patch and also the other one for nova : https://review.openstack.org/#/c/40544/"}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I've tested this with the changes to puppet-nova (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/40544/), puppet-openstack (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/40547/), and puppet-horizon(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/40705/, and puppet-tempest (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/40697/) and had no errors."}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Can a redirect be configured at GitHub? People are often using the repository for fixtures and deployment.

How about Gerrit? Would it be relevant?'}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 7822, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

If we're going to merge this, I'd prefer that we hold off for a few more days or make Grizzly and Havana branches. If head is targeting Havana, then this makes sense. Otherwise we should wait for the Havana release to make the global change."}, {'account_id': 7822, 'date': '2013-08-08 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Rename quantum to neutron.

Global replacement of all Quantum references with Neutron.

commit_message:
Add default auth_uri setting for auth token.

The latest keystoneclient code now gives a Warning if auth_uri
isn't explicitly specified.

Change-Id: I6c5978df0c363069700578dbeb787c385fde4e96

commit_message:
PowerShell functions updated.

* More traps
* Assign undesirable output to $null
* Reorganize some execution plans

Change-Id: Ifb877ba3facc526baa2855432ad2d408cf23cb98

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-24 20:28:49.000000000', 'message': 'BaseException.message is deprecated since Python 2.6

PEP 352 deprecated the message attribute of the BaseException class.
Using the message attribute will result in warnings like this:

DeprecationWarning: BaseException.message has been deprecated as of Python 2.6

commit_message:
BaseException.message is deprecated since Python 2.6

PEP 352 deprecated the message attribute of the BaseException class.
Using the message attribute will result in warnings like this:

DeprecationWarning: BaseException.message has been deprecated as of Python 2.6

Using unicode(exc) is the suggested replacement.

Change-Id: Ie322aaa69c025ae5bf39d00f7e3487fe2527545b

commit_message:
Catch ldap ImportError

Since the `ldap` module isn't a requirement, we need to guard against it not
being present.

One reason this is needed is that we generate sample configs by walking the
module import tree. If a module isn't importable--because a depenency isn't
met, for example--the module's configs are omitted from the sample config,
requiring the developer to manually add them back.

Fixes bug 1208560

Change-Id: Ie23b7fad118ecadabf7e36703934fa933f4e8c50

Change-Id: I96b688511b35014a8c006e4d30b875dcaf409d93
'}, {'created': '2013-06-07 01:41:22.000000000', 'message': 'Start refactoring create to use taskflow.

Move the create_volume workflow to using taskflow and
split that function into 3 major pieces (each with there
own workflow).

1. An api workflow composed of the following tasks
  - Extracting volume request (which checks types, values)
  - Quota reservation (rolled back on failure)
  - Database entry creation
  - Quota committing
  - Volume casting (rpc)
2. A scheduler workflow composed of the following tasks
  - Extracting scheduler request specification
  - Change status & notify (activated only on failure)
  - Create volume scheduler driver call
3. A manager workflow composed of the following tasks
  - Extract volume request specification
  - Change status & notify on failure or reschedule on
    failure (dependent on if rescheduling is enabled)
  - Create volume from specification
    - This contains the code to create from image, create
      raw volume, create from source volume, create from
      snapshot
  - Change status & notify success.

Change-Id: I96b688511b35014a8c006e4d30b875dcaf409d93

'}, {'created': '2013-06-13 01:46:23.000000000', 'message': 'Refactoring of create_volume to use taskflow.

Move the create_volume workflow to using taskflow and
split that function into 3 major pieces (each with there
own workflow).

1. An api workflow composed of the following tasks
  - Extracting volume request (which checks types, values)
  - Quota reservation (rolled back on failure)
  - Database entry creation
  - Quota committing
  - Volume casting (rpc)
2. A scheduler workflow composed of the following tasks
  - Extracting scheduler request specification
  - Change status & notify (activated only on failure)
  - Create volume scheduler driver call
3. A manager workflow composed of the following tasks
  - Extract volume request specification
  - Change status & notify on failure or reschedule on
    failure (dependent on if rescheduling is enabled)
  - Create volume from specification
    - This contains the code to create from image, create
      raw volume, create from source volume, create from
      snapshot
  - Change status & notify success.

Change-Id: I96b688511b35014a8c006e4d30b875dcaf409d93
'}, {'created': '2013-06-13 05:25:56.000000000', 'message': 'Refactoring of create_volume to use taskflow.

Move the create_volume workflow to using taskflow and
split that function into 3 major pieces (each with there
own workflow).

1. An api workflow composed of the following tasks:
  - Extracting volume request (which checks types, values).
  - Quota reservation (rolled back on failure).
  - Database entry creation.
  - Quota committing.
  - Volume casting (rpc).
2. A scheduler workflow composed of the following tasks:
  - Extracting scheduler request specification.
  - Change status & notify (activated only on failure).
  - Create volume scheduler driver call.
3. A manager workflow composed of the following tasks:
  - Extract volume request specification.
  - Change status & notify on failure or reschedule on
    failure (dependent on if rescheduling is enabled).
  - Create volume from specification
    - This contains the code to create from image, create
      raw volume, create from source volume, create from
      snapshot.
  - Change status & notify success.

Other benefits:
  - Handled exceptions in a better way than they are currently being handled
  - Rescheduling is now easier to understand.
  - Easier to understand structure.

Future additions:
  - Eventual addition of resumption logic to recover from operations stopped
    halfway through.
  - Ability to centrally orchestrate the tasks and pick and choice how
    reconciliation of failures based on code or policies.

Change-Id: I96b688511b35014a8c006e4d30b875dcaf409d93

1. An api workflow composed of the following tasks:
  - Extracting volume request (which checks types, values).
  - Quota reservation (rolled back on failure).
  - Database entry creation.
  - Quota committing.
  - Volume casting (rpc).
2. A scheduler workflow composed of the following tasks:
  - Extracting scheduler request specification.
  - Change status & notify (activated only on failure).
  - Create volume scheduler driver call.
3. A manager workflow composed of the following tasks:
  - Extract volume request specification.
  - Change status & notify on failure or reschedule on
    failure (dependent on if rescheduling is enabled).
  - Create volume from specification
    - This contains the code to create from image, create
      raw volume, create from source volume, create from
      snapshot.
  - Change status & notify success.

Other benefits:
  - Handled exceptions in a better way than they are currently being handled
  - Rescheduling is now easier to understand.
  - Easier to understand structure.

Future additions:
  - Eventual addition of resumption logic to recover from operations stopped
    halfway through.
  - Ability to centrally orchestrate the tasks and pick and choice how
    reconciliation of failures based on code or policies.

Part of bp: cinder-state-machine

commit_message:
Refactoring of create_volume to use taskflow.

Move the create_volume workflow to using taskflow and
split that workflow into three major pieces (each with
there own workflow) and create tasks that perform the
individual required actions to accomplish the pieces
desired outcome.

1. An api workflow composed of the following tasks:
  - Extracting volume request (which checks types, values) and creates a
    standard output for other tasks to work on (allowing further tasks to be
    plugged in the chain without having to worry about other tasks output
    formats).
  - Quota reservation (rolled back on failure).
  - Database entry creation.
  - Quota committing.
  - Volume RPC casting to volume scheduler or to targeted volume manager.
2. A scheduler workflow composed of the following tasks:
  - Extracting scheduler request specification for further tasks to use.
  - Change status & notify (activated only on failure).
  - Create volume scheduler driver call (which will itself RPC cast to a
    targeted volume manager).
3. A manager workflow composed of the following tasks:
  - Extract volume request specification from incoming request for
    further tasks to use. This also breaks up the incoming request into the 4
    volume types that can be created later.
  - Change status & notify on failure or reschedule on failure, this is
    dependent on if rescheduling is enabled *and* which exception types are
    thrown from the volume creation code.
  - Create volume from specification
    - This contains the code to create from image, create raw volume, create
      from source volume, create from snapshot using the extracted volume
      specification.
  - Change status & notify success.

Key benefits:
  - Handled exceptions in a easier to understand, easier to review and more
    reliable way than they are currently being handled.
  - Rescheduling is now easier to understand.
  - Easier to understand structure with tasks that consume inputs, take some
    action on them and produce outputs and revert on subsequent failure using
    whatever they produced to know how to revert.
  - Ability to add new unit tests that can test individual task actions by
    providing mock task inputs and validating expected task outputs.

Future additions:
  - Eventual addition of resumption logic to recover from operations stopped
    halfway through.
  - Ability to centrally orchestrate the tasks and pick and choice how
    reconciliation of failures based on code or policies.

Part of bp: cinder-state-machine

Change-Id: I96b688511b35014a8c006e4d30b875dcaf409d93

Encryption is implemented by passing all data written to and read
from the logical volumes through a dm-crypt layer. Most instance
operations such as pause/continue, suspend/resume, reboot, etc. are
supported. Snapshots are also supported but are not encrypted at
present.

When fully functional, the proposed code will provide data-at-rest
security for all ephemeral storage drives, preventing access to data
while the instance or compute host are shut down.

Implements: blueprint Encryption of ephemeral storage

commit_message:
Adds ephemeral storage encryption

This patch adds ephemeral storage encryption for LVM back-end instances.
Encryption is implemented by passing all data written to and read
from the logical volumes through a dm-crypt layer. Most instance
operations such as pause/continue, suspend/resume, reboot, etc. are
supported. Snapshots are also supported but are not encrypted at
present.

When fully functional, the proposed code will provide data-at-rest
security for all ephemeral storage drives, preventing access to data
while the instance or compute host are shut down.

Implements: blueprint encrypt-ephemeral-storage
Change-Id: I7c44f1346a7e07c806d1afcaa050d5d0c5d5d0b0

commit_message:
Add Description Field to Domains/Records

Adds a description field to Domains and Records. Adds accompanying tests to
ensure that the field is UTF-8 compatible. Adds databse migration to add the
appropriate columns to the database.

Change-Id: Iaa1ac6aee01fadc409ea16298c83946f35bdde33
Implements: blueprint resource-notes

commit_message:
Add support for listing claimed messages (transport)

This patch adds a query parameter, "include_claimed", to
the GET messages operation, to allow the caller to specify
whether it wants to include claimed messages in the
listing (as opposed to the default of only listing active
messages).

Change-Id: Ie0ee4a435420fbc3c94a339836853a49b4196460
Fixes: bug #1202430

subject: Added Generic Persistence API and Datatypes
messages:
[{'account_id': 7366, 'date': '2013-08-02 16:01:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (5 inline comments)

Just a quick look, with couple of minor notes.

Kevin, is there any design document explaining what and why should be persistent?'}, {'account_id': 7366, 'date': '2013-08-06 13:28:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Great work, but I've got several doubts/questions about your design decisions.

The main reason is that I don't see how it is possible to restore the flow from database state. The main part of flow (imo) is the tasks, the code that should be executed, but on restore you just create generic task that is unable to perform anything useful. One possible solution is to re-create flow from the code and let it restore state from database, but then you don't need task dependencies (they are evident from code), just states and results.

Please share your thoughts on that.

As a non-related note: why do you need three unique ids for TaskDetails? task_id should be unique enough. Or am I missing something?

Also, this commit seems too large for me. It would be also much easier to review if you could split it into several changes."}, {'account_id': 7839, 'date': '2013-08-06 21:16:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ivan:
Q.) 5 inline comments
A.) I made most of the changes you suggested. Still learning how to use gerrit, so those will be applied as a patch set once I figure it out.

Q.) Kevin, is there any design document explaining what and why should be persistent?
A.) There is now! :). https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/TaskFlow/Persistence

Q.) The main reason is that I don't see how it is possible to restore the flow from database state...
A.) The persistence API is designed in a way to allow for customized storing of a flow and a restoration method to compliment the way it is stored. When the process of restoring a flow is defined, the process of restoring its tasks will be defined as well.

Q.) why do you need three unique ids for TaskDetails?
A.) There is only one unique ID for TaskDetails (self._uuid)

Q.) Also, this commit seems too large for me. It would be also much easier to review if you could split it into several changes.
A.) This was a pretty big subproject that came together as one unit. Sorry for the inconvenience."}, {'account_id': 6648, 'date': '2013-08-07 03:40:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I share the same concern with Ivan. This patch is simply too big too review...'}, {'account_id': 7366, 'date': '2013-08-07 06:06:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@kevin

> There is only one unique ID for TaskDetails (self._uuid)

As far as I understand task id is globally unique (it is uuid generated on task instance creation). You also added id to TaskDetail sqlalchemy model. That totals to three unique generated ids for one task detail (at least if you use sqlalchemy), which seems to be three times more than actually needed. But maybe I'm missing something."}, {'account_id': 7839, 'date': '2013-08-07 15:08:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Ivan:
The reason for a Task uuid in addition to a TaskDetail's own uuid is because a TaskDetail is supposed to record the data associated with each run of a Task. All TaskDetails that describe the same Task will have the same task uuid, but will all have unique taskdetail uuids. I hope that helps clarify."}, {'account_id': 7366, 'date': '2013-08-07 16:01:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Kevin,

Thank you for clarifications. I forgot that some flows (like distributed flow Jessica works on) are able to run the same task several times.'}, {'account_id': 7839, 'date': '2013-08-07 19:23:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-07 19:56:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/33/39933/2/check/gate-taskflow-pep8/672517e : FAILURE in 1m 43s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33/39933/2/check/gate-taskflow-python27/093ed97 : SUCCESS in 1m 28s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33/39933/2/check/gate-taskflow-python26/8e1668f : SUCCESS in 1m 19s
"}, {'account_id': 7839, 'date': '2013-08-08 18:22:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Added Generic Persistence API and Datatypes

Added a generic persistence API for JobBoards,
Jobs, LogBooks, Workflows, FlowDetails, Tasks,
and TaskDetails. The currently implemented
backends are in-memory and sqlite db (by use
of sqlalchemy). Also implemented generic return
types (listed above) for the generic API.

Change-Id: I75140bcc9db9062a4c686f5a9774ae8b857baf25

commit_message:
Change logging in stress test

Stress tests is now using the default tempest logging in order to use
tempest.conf for configuration. Every action registers a logger for
their own (previously they reported always as "stresstest").

Cleanup function is adapted as well.

Implements: bp stress-tests

Change-Id: I571d4b1ad7ced62b5d5b3e7faf8fa1a7e5f9504e

commit_message:
Remove dead capabilities code

Although the scheduler.host_manager has logic to handle the
'allowed_vm_type' capabilities, no virt driver supports that capability.
So just remove the dead code.

Part of bp no-compute-fanout-to-scheduler

Change-Id: I223fc10a27291d88d0e12057504525233ab845ad

commit_message:
Puppet Forge 2.1.1 Release

Prior to this commit, the Modulefile incorrectly listed the
puppet-quantum module version as 0.2.2. This patch updates
the version to 2.1.1. As the repository has already been
given a release tag of 2.1.0, this is a candidate for a new
release with a minor bug fix version bump. No 2.1.0 module
will be available.

Change-Id: Id94800e318e4560b6ba5555f43f849d8df028f5a
(cherry picked from commit 2d55ecc9218b3796a5f012f752f0004016c10edf)

commit_message:
Implement the root and v1 entry points of the API

An resource is returned at the root URL of the API and contains
information about the API itself as well as links to the specific versions
of the API. Also, a resource is returned at the root URL of each specific
version of the API and contains information about the resources available
on that version, links to documentation and available content-types that
are supported.

Implements blueprint implement-root-api-action

commit_message:
Use utils.safe_minidom_parse_string in extensions

Use utils.safe_minidom_parse_string in extensions that were still
directly using potentially-unsafe minidom.

Grizzly backport of John Griffith's master patch.

Fixes bug 1190229

Change-Id: I43afb2e188bbea99ea30fe6cb2eb1aeedc4ddfd4

'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-04-16 16:29:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hey,

Thanks for the patch. 

I would prefer having that in a separate method, that would make the integration cleaner. Also, the client is in the process of migrating to python-requests: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/23424/ 

Thanks again."}, {'account_id': 7073, 'date': '2013-04-16 17:40:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for the review, i don't understand how you want this in a different method, and how you will do that !? and i don't understand what you mean when you say "integration" ? with what ? Can you please be more specific, and just so i can understand, are you suggesting to have the chunk iteration part in a different method or the printing/feedback part ?

As for the new patch, IMHO this patch can be integrated with that one easily, if we agreed about the way that should be implemented, by adding the printing part in the chunk_body inner method.

So hopefully this patch will be helpful to anybody as it was for me. Try to create a glance image of 20G e.g. windows images, with no feedback from glanceclient ;-)'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-04-16 19:10:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Thanks for the review, i don't understand how you want this in a different method, and how you will do that !? and i don't understand what you mean when you say "integration" ? with what ? Can you please be more specific, and just so i can understand, are you suggesting to have the chunk iteration part in a different method or the printing/feedback part ?

Hey,

Sorry for not being clear. Yeah, I was thinking about having it in a separate method (perhaps passing percentage and total) or even better (?) having a InputProgressIterator (horrible name) that gets in input a file like object, the chunk size and prints the progress every time a new chunk is read. Thoughts? 


> As for the new patch, IMHO this patch can be integrated with that one easily, if we agreed about the way that should be implemented, by adding the printing part in the chunk_body inner method.

Yep, that's what I meant, in order to integrate this more easily (without changes) I suggested to have it in a separated method (or iterator as suggested above)   

> So hopefully this patch will be helpful to anybody as it was for me. Try to create a glance image of 20G e.g. windows images, with no feedback from glanceclient ;-)

ouch!

It is indeed useful.

Thanks again'}, {'account_id': 7073, 'date': '2013-04-17 08:14:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks for the quick response, but there is still something bothering me, is why we need it in a different method ? Why we need a Wrapper ? Will it be used somewhere else ? If so can you please in-light me on the use cases that are intended to be used in ? If there is it will be helpful so i can design this better.

Because from my side this change is almost similar to adding logging statement in a code for user feedback, and because i don't see where this can be used except here, i fail to understand the need for making it generic, and unless i am failing to understand something obvious i think we should apply the YAGNI principal here.

In term of code what i am trying to tell is, why not import this change for the requests integration patch like this:


      ... initialize totalsize percent ...
     def chunk_body(body):
            chunk = body
            while chunk:
               chunk = body.read(CHUNKSIZE)
               yield chunk
               sys.stdout.write('\r[{:<30}] {:.0%}'.format( '=' * int(percent * 30) + '>', percent ))
               percent ...

One thing that i was thinking to do if we want to controller when to show/hide the progress bar, is to add a new command line argument, --progress (available only for image-create, maybe ?), that could be passed to the http_request as show_progress=True argument and by default it will be False.

Thanks again,"}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-04-17 08:29:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hey :D

Thanks for your comments!

So, I see two reasons to wrap this out:

1) It would make it easier to port to the new change (Silly reason, I know)
2) We could actually re-factor ResponseBodyIterator and use this implementation for both downloads and uploads.

The later is the one I'm most interested in, and even though python-requests implementation is not using ResponseIterator yet, It'd be easy to port.

Thoughts?

Great feedback, thanks!"}, {'account_id': 7073, 'date': '2013-04-17 09:57:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi,

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2013-04-26 17:34:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Do not merge

I think the progressbar logic should be abstracted into a new iterator we can wrap around image data in the v1/shell.py and v2/shell.py. This logic does not belong in the common http client.

Additionally, the progressbar feature should be off by default and controllable with a --progress flag when uploading/downloading image data through the shell.'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-04-27 13:24:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Hey

> I think the progressbar logic should be abstracted into a new iterator we can wrap around image data in the v1/shell.py and v2/shell.py. This logic does not belong in the common http client.

mmmhhh, makes sense. I think some of the changes (like passing the content size to the iterator) should be kept and others could be moved in a separate iterator.

The body iterator is not used in the python-requests patch anymore so, getting this functionality out of http.py will make it definitely easier to integrate.

> Additionally, the progressbar feature should be off by default and controllable with a --progress flag when uploading/downloading image data through the shell.

I disagree. When using the command line, users might want to know if everything is working as expected and get some feedback. I would rather add a --no-progress (or --quite).

Thanks
FF'}, {'account_id': 7073, 'date': '2013-04-29 09:47:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 7073, 'date': '2013-04-29 10:02:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Hi,

Thanks for the review, here is a new tentative to do this which put the progress bar logic in the shell module as suggested.

In this change i had to expose the progress bar in a standalone module, because i needed to create 2 classes for each object type and 1 base class, i am still not satisfy with the current status of this later, so if there is any suggestion of improvement please let me know.

I agree with Flavio that the progress bar should be the default behavior, because I believe that any long running process **must** show user feedback of what it's doing.

Cheers,"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-29 10:31:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Works for me

Please check my comment'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-06-04 17:19:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: (2 inline comments)

Hi Mouad,

I am sorry this has been an unpleasant experience. We appreciate your code contribution, we just need to modify it before it can land. So far our processes for modifying submissions has not been well-developed for friendliness.

I think the best strategy here is to thank you for your contribution, hold it in temporary -1 status while someone else provides a cleanup patch that can mark this patch as a dependency. Then we can approve the cleanup patch. Once the cleanup patch is queued to land, we can approve this branch. 

Another approach would be to have someone push on top of this submission directly. That would preserve your ownership/authorship of the patch, but mark the other person as the submitter.

Do you have a preference between the two options above?'}, {'account_id': 7073, 'date': '2013-06-05 08:37:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: (1 inline comment)

Hi Mark,

I have never said that i don't want to continue contributing on this, and i didn't find this unpleasant at all, maybe i wasn't clear about the point of my complain, what i have complained about is the "i don't like this" argument without given a good reason of why, that's all, and the complain wasn't wrote by an angry person i think i have put enough smily faces there to make the point that i am being friendly about my suggestion :), so if someone want to take anything from my complain it will be this: "Please share your though with contributors of why to improve a given code so that everyone is kept in the loop and that future visitor of a patch understand why it was implemented this way".

So please do not ban me from this, i have enjoyed all the learning steps while contributing this patch, i hope i wasn't out of line here, because i feel that i just made some people very upset and believe me it's not my intend at all.

Now if no one has any objection of me continuing this, we have now 2 options, either Flavio one which including using ResponseBodyIterator where we can set the size attribute and have a new method ResponseBodyIterator .checksum_iter that we call in the shell.py (@Flavio, right ? ), or what i have suggested which is almost like Flavio except that we leave the current Image.data behavior as it is (doing the checksum) but we change it to return a new wrapper iterator that hold the size attribute.

Thanks for your patience and looking forward to your ideas :)'}, {'account_id': 7073, 'date': '2013-06-05 13:14:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 7073, 'date': '2013-06-05 15:53:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-05 16:46:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Works for me

Hi, I think the progress bar code should probably be added to image-update as well, as this function may upload data to an image in queued state.

Appoligies for the late comment!"}, {'account_id': 7073, 'date': '2013-06-10 08:00:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Hi Hugh,

Good point, consider it done :)'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-06-10 23:17:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Hi Mouad,

Thanks so much for your recent updates. I don't believe anybody was upset by the discussion--I just imagined that if I were in your place I might be a bit frustrated by the way the review process played out. So I'm very glad to see your latest patch.

You're very correct, it is important for reviewers to give good reasons behind proposed changes.

I did not mean to give the impression of any sort of banning--indeed I'm sure that's neither possible nor desirable in any contributor's case. I only meant to suggest that there was a lot of value in your contributions even if you did not have the time to go through with picky refactorings (even if those picky refactorings are ultimately necessary). But since you've already refactored the patch, the point is now moot.

Thanks, again!"}, {'account_id': 7073, 'date': '2013-06-17 09:02:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 7073, 'date': '2013-06-17 09:03:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-17 09:43:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Works for me

Hi Joshua,

I originally tried to look at this package if it can be of any help, but i dropped out because i wasn't able to find any documentation for this package (maybe my google-fu is not that good :)), and this is only my personal opinion but i don't use project which doesn't have a documentation specially if i can create the functionality that i want faster than looking where is this project documentation ;-)

But sure this may change in the future if we want to add more stuff in the progress bar, but IMHO for now i think we can live without it.

Thanks :)"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-07-04 18:12:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

commit_message:
Show a pretty progressbar when uploading and downloading an image.

Add a new module that contain generic wrapper for file and iterator, which
are used to wrap image to upload and the request body iterator in upload and
download cases repectively, to show and advance a pretty progress bar when this
laters are consumed, The progress bar is triggered by adding a --progress command
line argument to commands: image-create, image-download or image-update.

Change-Id: I2ba42fd0c58f4fa087adb568ec3f08246cae3759
bug fix: LP#1112309
blueprint: progressbar-when-uploading

commit_message:
Remove raw_template_get_all from db api

This is not used anywhere in the code base anymore, and does not
seem to be useful in the future.

Change-Id: I5964bc0d402abdb5dde889a4c605fe4d4b4b1376

commit_message:
Provide a way to clean up soft deleted data

Add a purge_deleted command to heat-manage. The command takes an
'age' argument, and removes all database records that have been soft
deleted for more than 'age' days. Default to 90.

blueprint event-persistence

Change-Id: I8a62108a907b4e709c91a93a1f7db6c702cec6b5

subject: Enable stack soft delete for event persistence

recheck no bug'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-08-05 13:16:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

I don't see the need for all these arguments and defaults.

* stack_get() should always include deleted stacks because if you ask for a stack by id then you want it. There are no circumstances in which you would ask for it but not want it. That's why you've had to override the default in basically every single place.
* Same thing for event_get(). If you ask for it by ID, it's because you want it.
* Similar deal for event_get_all_by_stack(), except that there you've already got the stack (which may have been deleted) even. Why filter again on the basis of state that is already known to the caller at the time of the request?
* Ditto for raw_template_get(). If the DB schema were more sensible, that would just be part of stack_get().
* Conversely, stack_get_by_name should never return deleted stacks, because stack names are not unique over time.
* Unrelated to this patch, why does raw_template_get_all() even exist?
* stack_get_all[_by_tenant]() should probably never return deleted stacks.

I especially don't understand getting the show_deleted option from context.show_deleted. For a start, I can't actually find where this is being set. But also, it doesn't make sense in a lot of cases... for example stack_get_by_name() returns the first name match it finds. So if I set context.show_deleted to True and there is a name collision, it will return one essentially at random. So this is basically a "show me random data" config option? Why would I want that?

Also, could we please have any unit test changes that are independent of this (e.g. clearing the database between tests, refactoring UUID stubs) submitted as separate patches (one for every independent change) before this in the queue.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-05 13:28:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

'}, {'account_id': 7135, 'date': '2013-08-06 08:29:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Hi Zane, thank you very much for the comments.

Agree, this is indeed not necessary sometimes.
1. I had the same feeling and it was implemented that way until I started testing the patch I realized that stack_get needs the show_deleted argument because we don't want delete, update, pause, resume operations to apply on deleted stacks.
2. Yeah, it should be safe to remove the show_deleted argument for event_get(). Will do.
3. Agree, not really necessary. will remove it.
4. Sure, I will remove the argument.
5. Yeah. But I didn't add the show_deleted argument to stack_get_by_name ;)
6. I don't see any reason to have raw_template_get_all either. I will remove it in a separate patch in the queue.
7. Yeah, I think so. And that is exactly how the stack_get_all[_by_tenant] behaves in the patch.

Getting show_deleted option from context.show_deleted is again another example on trying to be compatible with Oslo DB package, and I always have a tendency to leave more options for future usage. But as you pointed out it doesn't make sense in many cases. I will remove that for now. And we can come back to it when we decide to integrate with the Oslo DB. Sorry for making the confusion.

And I will break this into separate patches as you suggested. Thanks again."}, {'account_id': 7135, 'date': '2013-08-06 08:34:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Great, thanks!

I agree with all your comments, except I'm not completely sure about the delete/update/suspend/resume operations... I'm inclined to think we should load the stack from the DB and then check for invalid states (DELETE_COMPLETE is far from the only invalid state, so there's no _particular_ reason to make a special case for it, except that we can). There are probably fixes required there, and if so they should go in a separate patch, but it would probably simplify this one if they went in before this.

Thanks for the info about oslo.db, that explains a lot ;). Sounds like that would be a useful feature for the list_stacks call."}, {'account_id': 7135, 'date': '2013-08-07 00:49:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-07 01:47:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Enable stack soft delete for event persistence

Instead of removing database records when deleting data from stack,
table, mark them as deleted through the deleted_at field. And allow
access to soft deleted records by stack Id.

blueprint event-persistence

Change-Id: Iaddd9ba683deab65a9b2be3cc2e727c34e816dd4

subject: xenapi: remove propagate xenapi_use_agent key

[{'created': '2013-07-25 14:38:31.000000000', 'message': 'xenapi: propagate xenapi_use_agent key on snapshot

system_metadata is being incorrectly accessed. This changes makes use of
the appropriate utility function to ensure the key is correctly
propagated to the snapshot.

The compute.api class will already propagate then xenapi_use_agent key
when required, so we can remove the xenapi specific code that tries to
propagate this value. The code did not correctly access the system
metadata, would have failed to propagate the key anyway.

Fixes bug 1204933

commit_message:
xenapi: remove propagate xenapi_use_agent key

The compute.api class will already propagate then xenapi_use_agent key
when required, so we can remove the xenapi specific code that tries to
propagate this value. The code did not correctly access the system
metadata, would have failed to propagate the key anyway.

Fixes bug 1204933
Change-Id: Ib291a265318d80705129e565155d4250fd704b75

commit_message:
Don't check for active messages

Instead of counting to check whether there are active messages, try to
fetch ids right away and use len on the result. This removes 1 query
from the claim process.

Fixes bug: #1207759

Change-Id: I579d09ed026d0889ded2463d4807154c8259109d

I think those queues should be sorted on return. Does mongo handle this for us? If not, does the transport layer do some sorting before returning results to the user?'}, {'account_id': 6944, 'date': '2013-08-06 16:22:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

The only thing I've noticed regarding API changes is what Zhihao pointed out. I'm on the fence about 204 vs. 404 for listing messages from a missing queue. Semantically and in the context of the HTTP standard, 404 is the correct choice, since neither of the resources were found. Pragmatically, 204 makes me think of the Maybe pattern from functional languages. Maybe we get messages back, maybe we don't - it gives the client more freedom to interpret this as a success or a failure, IMO, which is reasonable for a listing operation.

LGTM."}, {'account_id': 8092, 'date': '2013-08-06 16:26:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Use queue's name and project to get messages

Mongodb's driver currently queries the queue's collection to get queue
id and then filter messages with it. Instead of storing the id, this
patches stores the queue name and the project in the message collection
and use that for querying messages.

It's safe to assume that the queue exists when messages are returned by
the query, however, posts operation will still verify queue's existence.

Fixes bug: #1207018

Change-Id: Iaa7bc3f1300b3349a5cfad5a9f6ecabb2f75e95e

commit_message:
Remove nose from setup_requires

It's not really a setup_require. nose is not needed to run setup.py.

Change-Id: Ib2e22fe1be40a1feeca4bf7d35ed1797bdb10de8

commit_message:
Remove unsafe XML parsing

Move to using xmlutils for all XML parsing. Resolves bug 1190229.
Grizzly backport of Mikal Still's master patch.

Change-Id: I43afb2e188bbea99ea30fe6cb2eb1aeedc4ddfd4

confusing for the next change to land

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-08 16:34:44.000000000', 'message': "Allow _sync_power_states periodic task to hit slave DB

This commit allows those who have slave_connection configured
to have reads from _sync_power_states hit that connection. This
change does not affect anyone who doesn't have a slave. The
behavior remains the same for them.

Change-Id: I20d2c97c5c06e7584b464e96ef931942f7d3dd80
Implements: blueprint periodic-tasks-to-db-slave
"}]
commit_message:
Allow _sync_power_states periodic task to hit slave DB

This commit allows those who have slave_connection configured
to have reads from _sync_power_states hit that connection. This
change does not affect anyone who doesn't have a slave. The
behavior remains the same for them.

Change-Id: I20d2c97c5c06e7584b464e96ef931942f7d3dd80
Implements: blueprint periodic-tasks-to-db-slave

commit_message:
feat(api): GET and HEAD methods on queue

To allow

    GET/HEAD /queues/a-queue

gives users an intuitive approach to test whether the queue exits,
while the URI above is returned as the Location header by a queue's
PUT method.

Implements: blueprint queue-get-and-head
Fixes: bug #1207075

Change-Id: Iefd3236a739b1a5d959efb489fc2b966ee893599

commit_message:
Don't attempt to patch eventlet without the patch

Some projects, like horizon, do not carry the eventlet patch.

Change-Id: I24ffad9ab7852be44e5d6c8805aa0a47647e21cc

commit_message:
Initial KDS service

THis is a duplicate of simos patch, but submitted as WIP as it will do
the migrations in a separate repo, and thus has a separate commit id.

Do not merge.

The Key Distribution Service is used to register keys for services and
distribute tickets to contact othe services.

The KDS is used to digitally sign and optionally encrypt messages sent over the
message queue by the rpc modules.

It implements the service described in this document:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/MessageSecurity#A_Key_Distribution_Server_in_Keystone

blueprint key-distribution-server
Signed-off-by: Simo Sorce <simo@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I74fb8b16bf09ce97b07e6058257ba40bdb8f3b60

exception_to_str() seems unnecessary.

logging.info() handles Unicode just fine. If it's failing somewhere, it has to be how Glance sets up logging.

Also, assuming UTF-8 will be used for all logging targets is a bad idea. All strings should be Unicode and let the target convert to the appropriate character set.

Not to mention that this will make supporting Python 3 harder too."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-07-25 15:34:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-07-25 22:14:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

Hey Johannes Erdfelt

I think exception_to_str() is necessary. the problem for this bug it not happened on logging.warn() calling, it failed on string join: line #44 in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/37421/4/glance/store/base.py .'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-07-25 22:57:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

It looks like this is the problem you're having:

    >>> e = Exception(u'\u2022')
    >>> 'test: %s' % e
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
    UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\u2022' in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)

There's a couple of possible fixes:

    >>> u'test: %s' % e
    u'test: \u2022'

or

    >>> 'test: %s' % unicode(e)
    u'test: \u2022'

In either case, we really want to keep all strings in a unicode type for as long as possible. The conversion to any other encoding (utf-8, windows-1252, etc) should happen at the edges (writing to screen, log file, etc). Especially since there might be multiple different encodings used at those edges.

Also, this ensures we use one normalized encoding (the Python unicode type) internally. Mixing different encodings will cause problems.'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-07-26 02:08:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Overall I agreed, but if you check the details of bug 1202098 , you can see the inconsistent encoding string be raised at https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/store/sheepdog.py#L207 , and this point exactly is the edges for the store driver by the driver developer's perspective. So, I consider the 'exception_to_str()' function which perform maximum conversion is necessary on driver's direct wrapper layer. In Py3 the default encoding is unicode, py2 is ascii."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-07-26 05:05:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

It doesn't matter who or where raises an exception that has has unicode characters, the solution is the same.

I'm confused why you changed your patch. It was correct to start with. Even your commit message is correct!"}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-07-26 10:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

@Johannes Erdfelt, take look this: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/37421/1/glance/store/base.py'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-07-26 14:04:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Zhi, I have already looked at patch 1. (How else would I know it was correct?)

Flavio is mistaken for all of the reasons I've given previously.

Your current patch is more complicated than it needs to be and in fact introduces bugs.

Here's a some good sources for why you should decode early (not relevant for this discussion) and why you should encode late:
http://farmdev.com/talks/unicode/
http://eric.themoritzfamily.com/python-encodings-and-unicode.html

Take this as an example: Someone has configured their logging setup to use UTF-16 or UTF-32. What will your last patch do? What will your first patch do?

Ultimately, the encoding choice is not your decision! It's the users decision. Don't make it for them. This is why we want to do the encoding as late as possible, where the user can make that decision for themselves."}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-08-02 09:51:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

@Johannes 

Hey,

Thanks for your comments!

I've a couple of questions:

How does this patch complicates things? 

For us, the most important thing here is being able to log the actual error w/o hiding it behind other errors.

What bugs does this patch introduce?

IMHO, the patch is keeping everything decoded as long as possible. The encoding happens right before calling logging.

Pls, share your ideas about how to fix this if you still consider this approach is wrong. Unfortunately, calling unicode is not enough nor it is passing everything to the logging module.

One last comment:

I'm not sure logging module can handle decode / encode just fine, see the example bellow:

    >>> import logging
    >>> FORMAT = "%(asctime)-15s %(clientip)s %(user)-8s %(message)s"
    >>> logging.basicConfig(format=FORMAT)
    >>> d = {'clientip': '192.168.0.1', 'user': Exception(u'ni\xf1o')}
    >>> logging.warning("Protocol problem: %s", "connection reset", extra=d)
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/logging/__init__.py", line 851, in emit
        msg = self.format(record)
      File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/logging/__init__.py", line 724, in format
        return fmt.format(record)
      File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/logging/__init__.py", line 467, in format
        s = self._fmt % record.__dict__
    UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\xf1' in position 2: ordinal not in range(128)
    Logged from file <stdin>, line 1
    >>> logging.warning(u"Protocol problem: %s", "connection reset", extra=d)
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/logging/__init__.py", line 851, in emit
        msg = self.format(record)
      File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/logging/__init__.py", line 724, in format
        return fmt.format(record)
      File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/logging/__init__.py", line 467, in format
        s = self._fmt % record.__dict__
    UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\xf1' in position 2: ordinal not in range(128)
    Logged from file <stdin>, line 1
    >>> u'ni\xf1o'
    u'ni\xf1o'
    >>> print u'ni\xf1o'
    niño

Thanks again!'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-08-02 14:52:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Please go back and read all of the previous comments. I've explained the potential problems and even proposed some thought experiments for you to think through.

As far as your example goes:

1) It's nonsensical. Why is user an exception?
2) It has nothing to do with what the patch is trying to fix
3) It works fine if you make the format a unicode string too

    >>> import logging
    >>> FORMAT = u"%(asctime)-15s %(clientip)s %(user)-8s %(message)s"
    >>> logging.basicConfig(format=FORMAT)
    >>> d = {'clientip': '192.168.0.1', 'user': Exception(u'ni\xf1o')}
    >>> logging.warning("Protocol problem: %s", "connection reset", extra=d)
    2013-08-02 07:49:44,833 192.168.0.1 niño     Protocol problem: connection reset'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-08-05 11:33:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hey @Johannes

Thanks again for your reply.

I did read your comments before posting, actually, my questions were based on those comments and the purpose was to summarize your concerns and try to address them either by changing the patch or clarifying possible doubts. If you're still interested, pls, answer those questions or attend to our next meeting and bring this patch up for discussion under the "Open Discussion" topic.

Re: the example. I'm afraid you missed the whole point of it. I didn't expect you to interpret the message itself but to help me understand what you exactly meant with "logging can handle unicode perfectly", which I still think it doesn't. If you pass a unicode as message and then use a non-unicode string for the arguments, it'll fail anyway. This is why we need to make sure we pass encoded strings to logging and more importantly, this is why we take care of the whole encoding process ourselves. Pls, find bellow an example of what I just said. Also, it has everything to do with the patch since the whole point here is being able to log non-ascii characters that might be present in some exceptions.

In summary, as far as this patch goes, I still think it solves our issue and implements it in a way we can re-use the code for future cases.

Thanks for your thoughts.

>>> import logging
>>> FORMAT = u"%(asctime)-15s %(clientip)s %(user)-8s %(message)s"
>>> logging.basicConfig(format=FORMAT)
>>> d = {'clientip': '192.168.0.1', 'user': Exception("ni\xc3\xb1o")}                                                                                                                                                                          
>>> logging.warning("Protocol problem: %s", "connection reset", extra=d)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/logging/__init__.py", line 851, in emit
    msg = self.format(record)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/logging/__init__.py", line 724, in format
    return fmt.format(record)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/logging/__init__.py", line 467, in format
    s = self._fmt % record.__dict__
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 2: ordinal not in range(128)
Logged from file <stdin>, line 1
>>>'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-08-05 17:49:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Now I'm not saying that the logging module is perfect, but it can handle unicode just fine. It does need a little bit of help in some cases (mostly because of Python 2).

Your latest example shows exactly why you should be decoding strings early (you are using an encoded string in the exception).

You really want to keep "strings" internally in the unicode type if they can contain anything more than ASCII characters.

The reasons behind this are:
1) You never know what the user will want the output to be. Assuming utf-8 will disappoint anyone who doesn't use utf-8. The only safe thing to do is keep the string in a "normalized" format and then encode as late as possible where the code that finally outputs the string *does* know what the user wants
2) In python 3, str() is actually unicode() (for exactly the same reasons you should be using unicode() in python 2). Keeping everything in unicode() type is forward compatible with python 3, but encoding to utf-8 early isn't.

So why not use utf-8 as the normalized format internally? Because we already have the unicode() type that is specifically for this purpose plus it has a lot of extra functionality to makes code easier to write.

Here's yet another article that explains a lot of the reasons why you should decode early and encode late (as well as common frustrations with unicode in Python 2):

http://pythonhosted.org/kitchen/unicode-frustrations.html

And if you're looking for a code example for my utf-16 thought experiment:

    import codecs
    import logging
    class FileHandler(logging.StreamHandler):
        def __init__(self, filename, encoding):
            logging.StreamHandler.__init__(self)
            self.file = codecs.open(filename, mode='a', encoding=encoding)
        def emit(self, record):
            msg = self.format(record)
            print >>self.file, msg
    logger = logging.getLogger('')
    formatter = logging.Formatter(u'%(foo)s %(message)s')
    #formatter = logging.Formatter('%(foo)s %(message)s')
    terminal = logging.StreamHandler()
    terminal.setFormatter(formatter)
    logger.addHandler(terminal)
    logfile = FileHandler('utf-16.log', 'utf-16')
    logfile.setFormatter(formatter)
    logger.addHandler(logfile)
    logger.error('test', extra={'foo': u'\u2022'})          # Succeeds
    logger.error('test', extra={'foo': u'\u2022'.encode('utf-8')})  # FAIL

In this example there are two handlers being written to for every log line. The first is a normal StreamHandler for sys.stderr which will encode to whatever your terminal is (usually utf-8).

The second is a simple handler to write to a utf-16 encoded log file.

So to summarize, not only is the original version of this patch smaller, it's also easier to use, doesn't make assumptions about what the user wants and is also forward compatible with Python 3.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-08-06 18:59:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I finally think I understand the complex issues around this thread! Hooray!

Johannes, thanks so much for your input. I feel like I've learned a good bit about a sensible encode/decode philosophy.

I think one issue we run into when discussing this patch is that the degree to which the glance project "owns" the store drivers is somewhat confusing. I think we all agree that is best to convert the exception messages to unicode as early as possible--ideally you would never actually create an exception message that was not unicode. In this view, if we owned the store drivers 100%, we would just perform the unicode() cast directly in the store drivers before instantiating the Exception objects.

However, if we do not completely own the drivers, it makes sense to view the first point of entry of the non-unicode string as when the exception is raised. If we hold that view, it makes sense to catch the exceptions and encode their messages in glance.store.base. Since that is my view, I am generally in favor of the patch.

I believe another one of Johannes' concerns is that, as a result of not decoding/encoding at the correct times, we will end up sprinkling ugly conversion calls throughout the code. I see this approach as inappropriate, as I expect many of the conversion calls we add would be unnecessary, yet no amount of sprinkling would guarantee that we have caught all the bugs in the same class. In this sense, its clear that putting encoding and assertions at the boundaries of our code is the correct approach.

For that reason, I believe we should not make the conversion a utility function. Instead, it should be defined in glance.store.base not far from where it is used. We should not suggest that it be more widely used in other portions of the code.

So to summarize, I think we should keep the conversion step as it is in glance.store.base, but move the utility function to a private function in the same glance.store.base module.

Thanks to everyone for talking this one out. Again, I feel like I really learned something and am glad to see everyone engaged in figuring out the best approach.'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-08-07 05:44:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-07 06:30:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

- http://logs.openstack.org/21/37421/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-testr-full/c8eff50 : FAILURE in 28m 50s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/21/37421/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/d761a21 : SUCCESS in 45m 50s
- http://logs.openstack.org/21/37421/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron/13a3881 : SUCCESS in 22m 44s
- http://logs.openstack.org/21/37421/5/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/340e2f4 : SUCCESS in 26m 20s
'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-08-07 16:11:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-08-07 17:02:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Mark, I'm not sure you completely understand the problem here since you are making this to be a more complex problem than it really is.

Calling .encode() on a unicode type should *only* be done at the latest possible time (ie right before it *needs* to be a specific encoding).

In this case, it should be done by whatever logging handlers have been configured. This is because there may be multiple logging handlers and each one may want to use a different encoding. You *should not* define policy (like strutils.safe_encode() does implicitly by using utf-8 encoding). Letting the logging handlers do the encoding is the most sensible behavior.

Exceptions should *only* be converted to unicode type using the unicode() constructor. str() should *never* be used on an exception since the exception may contain more than ASCII characters.

As a result, _exception_to_str() is unnecessary. Since exceptions should *always* be converted using unicode(), there is no reason to ever call str() on an exception.

Also, since unicode() types should *never* be encoded early, it should *not* be done before calling logging.warn().

Anything that encodes a unicode type early is a bug.

Again, patch #1 is the correct way to fix this bug. It's also simpler and idiomatic."}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-08-08 07:48:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

TBH, I think we're all agreeing on the same think, the only bit that we're not agreeing on is the timing for this whole standard to land in Glance.

Glance does not handle unicode / str conversion correctly, yet. I've created a bug #1210031 for that with the hope we'll be able to close this issue once and for all.

Thanks for your thoughts."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-08 07:48:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: No score

commit_message:
Using unicode() convert non-English exception message

In non-English environment when the store driver loading failed, the
BackendException will be raised with a non-ascii message. We need call
unicode() to convert the message before using it.

Fixes bug 1202098

Change-Id: I9a58393b599aacc427cb4135988ecf5c3e90e455
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Exclude heat-cfn, heat-watch from pep8

They are due for removal in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/38228/
and are causing many H233 errors when using the syncronised
requirements versions.

commit_message:
Update BareMetal driver to current nova.network.model

Update baremetal driver and vif to use classes from
nova.network.model instead of legacy "network,mapping" tuple.

Partly implement blueprint nova-network-legacy

Co-author: Amir Sadoughi<amir.sadoughi@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ia66360f51e1d7a12273df2a080931958cc4f86b5

commit_message:
Use utils.safe_minidom_parse_string in extensions

Use utils.safe_minidom_parse_string in extensions that were still
using potentially-unsafe minidom.

Fixes bug 1190229

Change-Id: I43afb2e188bbea99ea30fe6cb2eb1aeedc4ddfd4

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-29 12:01:15.000000000', 'message': 'xenapi: no image upload retry on certain errors

There are a few upload errors that glance plugin should
not retry upload on, as it will fail again. This patch changes
upload to not retry on the following conditions in addition
to the 401 error that it already handles:

commit_message:
xenapi: no image upload retry on certain errors

There are a few upload errors that glance plugin should
not retry upload on, as it will fail again. This patch changes
upload to not retry on the following conditions in addition
to the 401 error that it already handles:

- CONFLICT
- REQUEST_ENTITY_TOO_LARGE
- PRECONDITION_FAILED
- FORBIDDEN

Fixes bug 1203726

Change-Id: I538a4f9b133169b2e398e7dfcb3af58fef204f03

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-02 09:47:19.000000000', 'message': 'Add call trace in error message

Call trace can help user to locate problem quickly.

stack.sh uses bash as interpreter, which defines a series of
"Shell Variables":
BASH_SOURCE:
An array variable whose members are the source filenames

BASH_LINENO:
An array variable whose members are the line numbers in source
files where each corresponding member of FUNCNAME  was  invoked.

FUNCNAME:
An array variable containing the names of all shell functions
currently in the execution call stack.

run "man bash" and search the variable name to get detailed info.

In function backtrace, it gets the call deepth from
${#BASH_SOURCE[@]}, then print the call stack from top to down.

In function die, backtrace is called with parameter "2" to ignore
the call trace of function "die" and "backtrace".

I add a broken function in lib/database, and call it in stack.sh,
the output looks like this:

[Call Trace]
./stack.sh:104:broken
/home/kui/osd/devstack/lib/database:24:die
[ERROR] ./stack.sh:24 It is broken

Fixes bug # 1207660

Change-Id: I04d0b3ccf783c769e41582c20f48694c19917334
'}]
commit_message:
Add call trace in error message

Call trace can help user to locate problem quickly.

stack.sh uses bash as interpreter, which defines a series of
"Shell Variables":
BASH_SOURCE:
An array variable whose members are the source filenames

BASH_LINENO:
An array variable whose members are the line numbers in source
files where each corresponding member of FUNCNAME  was  invoked.

FUNCNAME:
An array variable containing the names of all shell functions
currently in the execution call stack.

run "man bash" and search the variable name to get detailed info.

In function backtrace, it gets the call deepth from
${#BASH_SOURCE[@]}, then print the call stack from top to down.

In function die, backtrace is called with parameter "2" to ignore
the call trace of function "die" and "backtrace".

I add a broken function in lib/database, and call it in stack.sh,
the output looks like this:

[Call Trace]
./stack.sh:104:broken
/home/kui/osd/devstack/lib/database:24:die
[ERROR] ./stack.sh:24 It is broken

Fixes bug # 1207660

Change-Id: I04d0b3ccf783c769e41582c20f48694c19917334

commit_message:
Make TestResponse properly inherit Response.

There are a number of problems doing things like .json() if you don't
inherit the correct parameters.

Change-Id: I0dfc8ab6486090fbcd28792c18deae67e4769d53

commit_message:
Clarify staticweb configuration with keystone.

Since staticweb works with anonymous requests by default, explictly
mention delay_auth_decision for the authtoken middleware in
/etc/swift/proxy-server.conf.

Change-Id: I4879884b22224843cf9d4a50ba3359fac36957dc

commit_message:
Add apiclient library from oslo

This library can be used in novaclient, keystoneclient,
glanceclient, and other client projects. The library
contains common code and uses python-requests for
HTTP communication.

Features:
* reissue authentication request for expired tokens;
* pluggable authentication;
* rich exceptions hierarchy.

Partially implements: blueprint common-client-library

Change-Id: If3625074ebbba38a1bb998e637caf2b6b715b3fe
hange-Id: I9155613f012d7372b8a11e0950ac450b31a8c173

commit_message:
Add a heat-cfntools element for openshift-origin

heat-cfntools from the tripleo-image-elements repo is a bit heavyweight.

Instead this element simply installs the latest repo package of heat-cfntools
and symlinks to /opt/aws/bin.

Change-Id: I5a0ec433c352f3ac0bb415381c7e41d4370d1e85

commit_message:
Improve the L3 Agent support

New features:
- send_arp_for_ha
- periodic_interval
- periodic_fuzzy_delay
- enable_metadata_proxy

Fix bug #1207563

Change-Id: I890a6a9b4dc3eb3a189566578c5fbf5e31c145bf

We already depends on MongoDB >= 2.2

"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2013-07-17 12:54:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Just a general point about this first, is the recent sample TTL logic any concern here?

Specifically the cleaning up of dangling resources when there are no remaining samples for that resource due to TTL eviction?

Say some resource is suspended/stopped for a while so is no longer metered, TTL eventually kicks in and evicts all prior samples, resource is then resumed so that new first sample is newer than the "real" first sample.

Just a thought ...

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-07-17 13:02:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Not any concern here. We just return the lower and higher samples timestamp we have in the DB.

If some samples have been deleted because of ttl, that's for sure won't be the correct information, but anyway first will always be <= last.

There's no concept of "suspend" for resources. Even if it's suspended, it exists. If you want to filter your resource based on certain state, that's another problem (e.g. use metadata.vm_state in instances).'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2013-07-17 16:03:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Add first and last sample timestamp

When listing resources, it's useful to know where it started and where it
stopped. We don't have this precise information, but we can at least say
when we get the first and last timestamp.

Blueprint: api-v2-improvement

Change-Id: Icf678820bf7c3e6e12288b15623b653d9a942f21
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Rebuild openstack_dashboard static files after install.

This fixes problems with datagrid ugly look and broken buttons.

Change-Id: Ieb42c517ac6c4aaa286c0417b3cff700e12e9952

commit_message:
Create DB tables on Savanna start

Currently we need it for integration tests to work correctly.
Possibly we will remove it later.

commit_message:
feat(controller) : Implement Queue Controller

This patchset contributes a queue controller for Marconi client.
Allows getting messages, claiming messages, updating claims & releasing
them as well returning queue names and metadata.

Implements: blueprint queues-management
Change-Id: Idfd32f13bb1482e019fa8ebb85255bd90e6863c4

commit_message:
Use MongoDB aggregate to get resources list

This avoids querying two different collections to get the data, doing
aggregation on one is enough.

Change-Id: Ia21693051daefd1ebd4d0c7d07b76d4712b0542c

commit_message:
Internal SQLA Storage Consistency Cleanup

This will make adding paging support for all resources simpler, and
much more DRY.

Change-Id: I5a3c4e05a8565057066d98525e4c074a52a6b015

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-22 22:09:42.000000000', 'message': 'Add Instance.create()

This adds a create method to the Instance object and associated

Add Instance.create()

This adds a create method to the Instance object and associated
tests.

commit_message:
Add a fixture for dealing with config

Many tests change config's variables directly in CONF object. This
fixture allows to override the values in more convenient way and
restores config after test completion.

Blueprint: common-unit-tests
Change-Id: I5535c534425278d8804ca9fe84846e15ac898db0

commit_message:
Move tests test_update_* to separate class

Moved test_update_* in nova.tests.api.openstack.compute.plugins.v3.test_servers
and nova.tests.api.openstack.compute.test_servers to separate classes.

This commit is the first step in refactoring these files.
It will be followed by a commit which will remove duplicated code.

bp nova-tests-code-duplication

Change-Id: Ia78022d32962b846c62afc53ebb70fe17dda7931

commit_message:
Remove some FIXMEs and debug logging

These FIXMEs don't need fixing now that I think it through some more.
The reply format is specific to drivers and the 'ending' flag is part of
the existing wire protocol that we need to support even if we don't
support multicall().

Change-Id: I834f0bb01513b5318f0b365948a7d9247feb49bf

commit_message:
Remove unused IncomingMessage.done()

We appear to not have a use for this. I had originally thought we might
use this to ack messages one they've been processed and replied to, but
we actually have always acked messages as soon as they have been
deserialized and queued for dispatching.

Change-Id: I8e1fd565814f3b5e3ba0f1bc77e62ed52ff08661

Thanks Zhongyue

The right thing to do might be to just raise ValueError if timeout=0 is passed

It really doesn't make sense for a caller to say "wait for a reply, but wait zero seconds"

The only valid use of this is having a test that raises MessagingTimeout without actually sleeping'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-08-07 22:11:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

How about raise a ValueError if timeout < sys.float_info.epsilon? timeout passed to Queue and other libraries seems to be float.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-08-08 02:12:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

I guess timeout 0 is widely used in python if you look at select(), poll(), Condition.wait(), Lock.acquire(), and Thread.join().

Maybe we should add epsilon if timeout=0 until the bug is fixed.'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-08-08 13:09:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Implement wait_for_reply timeout in rabbit driver

Note - the tests use timeout=0.01 because timeout=0 doesn't seem to be
working for some reason.

Change-Id: I814a3decdad5ddce0a1a2301ba2d59fa928b53a7

commit_message:
Add OS::Heat::EventRecorder

This adds the ability to record alarm state changes in the events
table.
Resources:
  recorder:
    Type: OS::Heat::EventRecorder
...
      InsufficientDataActions:
      - {Ref: Recorder}

then you can see the alarm state changes from "heat event-list"
| MEMAlarmLow           | 547 | The alarm is within the threashold | alarm_NORMAL       | 2013-08-05T05:22:03Z |
| MEMAlarmHigh          | 548 | The alarm breached the threashold  | alarm_ALARM        | 2013-08-05T05:22:15Z |

blueprint event-recorder
Change-Id: I5ba12f09087420f5658e46683a409e907d0f1dfa

commit_message:
Replace ceilometer reference from openstack-compute to openstack-metering

Fix errors due to removed reference of openstack-compute ceilometer.
* add openstack-metering to metadata.rb
* add openstack-metering to Berksfile
* replace attr name from compute to metering

Change-Id: I2047fe226840d136e99bcc49970043476ffb2dbd

I guess you mean openstack-common in the commit message? It would also be great if you could keep the first line under 50 chars: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages#Summary_of_GIT_commit_message_structure"}, {'account_id': 8401, 'date': '2013-08-08 08:49:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yes, the commit message is wrong.  I specified the message in the command line. It should be added in the editor as follows:

-----------------------------
modified the depends "openstack-common" version

Currently, the latest openstack-common  cookbook 
 version is  0.4.3 . The depends "openstack-common" version  is " ~> 0.3.0" .  After uploading the 
openstack-common, I upload the "openstack-metering" 
cookbook. It output the dependency error. Modified the depends "openstack-common" version in the metadata.rb 
could fix it.

Fixes: bug #1210033
Implements: modified the depends "openstack-common" version 
Change-Id: I935f4659c5e0aaee632b114c90a60a7613b22e7e
---------------'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2013-08-08 08:52:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
modified the depends openstack-metering version

Currently, the latest openstack-common cookbook version is 0.4.3
The depends "openstack-common" version in the metadata.rb is
" ~> 0.3.0". After uploading the openstack-common, I upload the
"openstack-metering" cookbook. It output the dependency error.
Modified the depends "openstack-common" version in metadata.rb
could fix it.

Fixes: bug #1210033
Implements: modified the depends "openstack-common" version number
Change-Id: I935f4659c5e0aaee632b114c90a60a7613b22e7e

commit_message:
Refactor some tests for stack soft-delete

A few tests need to be refactored so that they will not break after
applying soft-delete on stack table.

blueprint event-persistence

Change-Id: I62d958521ca41717455d5a26756966cab8bf2bb7

commit_message:
Refactoring remote utils

* Add get_stderr flag to execute_command
* Add raise_when_error flag in execute_command function which raise
exception if command return non zero code
* Add waiting for generating id_rsa keyfile

Change-Id: Ica112e6b226a45ddc48e6f315b2c854da9ff292a

[{'created': '2013-08-07 14:20:53.000000000', 'message': 'Implement some restrictions on sync and primary columns in nodes datagrid.

* No more than 2 nodes in sync-mode are allowed;
* Primary node is always in sync-mode.

Change-Id: Ie367daa5b98c1cb0deb2944bc7ce146dac83059c
'}]
commit_message:
Implement some restrictions on sync and primary columns in nodes datagrid.

* No more than 2 nodes in sync-mode are allowed;
* Primary node is always in sync-mode.

Change-Id: Ie367daa5b98c1cb0deb2944bc7ce146dac83059c

commit_message:
Unit test for Conductor Manager improved

Covered:
* Clusters
* Node Groups
* Instances

Fixed db api to return ids where they are required.

Values argument is copied to keep it safe from modifications

Change-Id: Ifdd6295268fdac5bfa47c7cc824971e4a9d2c10f
